problem.tex: Let $f$ be an entire function such that $|f(z)|< M|z|^\alpha$ for all $z\in\mathbb{C}$, where $M,R,\alpha$ are constants and $0<\alpha<1$. Prove $f$ is constant.

solution.tex: Let $z_0\in\mathbb{C}$. Take the power series of $f$ centered at $0$, \[f(z)=\sum_{n=0}^\infty\frac{f^{(n)}(0)}{n!}z^n.\] Let $R>0$ and rewrite the coefficients using Cauchy's integral formula, \[f^{(n)}(0)=\frac{n!}{2\pi i}\int_{|w|=R}\frac{f(w)}{w^{n+1}}dw.\] Using the assumption that $|f(w)|< M|w|^\alpha$ gives \[|f^{(n)}(0)|\leq\frac{n!}{2\pi}\int_{|w|=R}\frac{MR^\alpha}{R^{n+1}}|dw|=\frac{n!M}{R^{n+1-\alpha}}.\] Now $n\geq0$ and $\alpha<1$ so $n+1-\alpha>0$. Thus $\frac{n!M}{R^{n+1-\alpha}}\to0$ as $R\to\infty$. We are using the fact that $f$ is entire when we let $R\to\infty$. Thus $f^{(n)}(0)=0$ for all $n\geq0$, meaning all coefficients in the power series are $0$, so $f$ is constantly 0. Note that we showed $f=0$, which is stronger than $f$ is constant. That is because of the way this question is worded, in fact $|f(0)|\leq M|0|^\alpha=0$ so $f$ being constant implies that $f$ is $0$ under this bound.
